STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 24, 2020
Kelli Arrendondo
Catholic Charities West Michigan - Benton Harbor
185 E. Main Street St.102
Benton Harbor, MI 49022
RE: License #: CB110403982
Catholic Charities West Michigan - Benton Harbor
185 E. Main Street St.102
Benton Harbor, MI 49022
Dear Ms. Arrendondo:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
September 18, 2020. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the
contract and Modified Implementation Sustainability, and Exit Plan (MISEP)
requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved; this includes identifying
behaviorally specific action steps.
o Repeat violations must include an explanation of why the previous
corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
 Individuals directly responsible for implementing the corrective action step for
each licensing statute and rule, Contract item, DHHS policy or MISEP section
citation, e.g. workers, supervisors, program managers, director, etc.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
implemented and completed.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved; this
includes identifying specific action steps for continuous monitoring.
o MiSACWIS users with access to the Book of Business, InfoView Reports
and the Monthly Child Welfare Management Report should incorporate the
use of these tools as well as other data management reports released by
the Department for continuous monitoring.
 Signature of the responsible party and date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Claudia Triestram, the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
Sincerely,
Paul Fatato, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
322 E. Stockbridge Ave
Kalamazoo, MI 49001
(269) 251-2471
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after placement.
One of three open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the dental examination was completed within the required 90-day time frame.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
DHHS Policy TIMELY ENTRY OF CASEWORKER CONTACTS
FOM 722-06H p
15
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS within
five business days of the contact.
Three of three open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
all social work contacts were entered into the MiSACWIS system in a timely manner.
The agency had three of nine contacts entered timely for a 33% compliance rate.
DHHS Policy DHHS-69 Action Summary
FOM 722-09C –
page 1-2
The Foster Care/Juvenile Justice (FC/JJ) Action Summary,
DHHS-69 (RFF 69), is used whenever there is “action” on a
case.
All foster care cases where there is:
3. A change in FC worker
4

One of three open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the required DHHS-69 was completed as required. This involved one DHHS-69 for a
worker change.
DHHS Policy Required Participation in Development – Foster Parent /
FOM 722-08C Caregiver
page 2
The foster parent is required to sign each Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
One of three open foster care case files reviewed did not have the caregiver’s
signature on the Parent Agency Treatment Plan for the Initial Service Plan. This
involved one ISP reviewed.
DHHS Policy Medical Passport
FOM 801-page
11-13
Updated Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
One of three open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation that
the required medical passport was completed as required. This involved one medical
passport.
DHHS Policy QUALITY VISITS
FOM 722-06H
Page 3
Quality visits between the caseworker and child have been
found to produce positive outcomes for children in foster care. A
quality visit is defined as one in which the caseworker:
- Meets with each child individually without the presence of
other individuals to give the child an opportunity to ask
questions.
- Assesses each child’s needs and takes appropriate action or
offers services in response to the identified need of each child.
- Shows interest in the individual child to build trust and
establish rapport.
- Shares and explains the case plan in a developmentally
appropriate way while allowing the child to ask questions and
express viewpoints.
5

One of three open foster care case files reviewed did not have documentation of a
quality visit documented for each social work contact. This involved one social work
contact.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Several items were not uploaded into the MiSACWIS system and we
discussed the importance of developing a system to ensure that staff are
aware and following through appropriately. The agency was receptive and
report that they will develop a system for compliance. We discussed different
ways of developing methods to ensure a positive change.
 Social work contacts were not always checked appropriately. This resulted in
the purpose of the contact not being identified as needed. The agency
acknowledged that they need to develop a method of oversite to make sure
this is occurring.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 The need for a comprehensive compliance system which will provide the
necessary oversite of case files was discussed. They report that the agency will
contact the compliance individual and ensure that a system is in place.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
The agency was not required to submitted any corrective action plans during this
licensing period.
Staff Interviews:
Three of four direct care workers were interviewed and all three report a positive
experience with the agency. They are all new workers and feel very supported by
the administration. Administration reports a strong desire to provide best practice
when providing services to the families and children. All report that the agency is
supportive during the COVID-19 issues and provide the necessary protective items.
6

VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
At the time of his report, the agency has no supervision of foster homes. There was
no need for the field analyst to conduct any inspection because of the lack of foster
homes.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
9/18/20
